ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to reconstruct and assess a philosophical argument.
Learned much about all the texts we read. I also improved at writing philosophy papers
modern philosophy and philosophical argument in essays - a good dose of epistemology and understanding immaterialism and empiricism
History of philosophy from Descartes to Anscombe. I significantly improved my writing when it comes to philosophy papers because I came to realise what the different expectations are.
Communicating and writing analysis of philosophical works.
Learned a lot about western philosophy, ex descartes, Hume, Berkeley

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the texts are very good.
Weaknesses: putting all of the texts in concert with another was not done as well as it should have been. Philosophical movements, etc.
This course is well made and organized well

Strengths: interesting reading selections
Weaknesses: un-engaging seminars, overall confusion about what exactly we were learning, Kant

Strengths: prof Greco is very smart, good essay comments and quick turnaround, lots of epistemology knowledge 

Weaknesses: not the most engaging, passion for material not always there, class could feel very slow

Strengths: covers a lot of material weaknesses: does not go deep enough in individual texts (except maybe Kant and Descartes). I wish we studied more existentialists/continental philosophers like Sartre and Schopenhauer especially because the latter was mentioned so many times in Nietzsche.

Strengths: material
Weaknesses: being able to debate the material, rather than just discuss it
The teacher wasn't too prepared during seminar

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it is a good survey of modern rationalist philosophy.
Yes, I would recommend this course because the texts we read are central to our society's beliefs

Spring semester DS phil is probably the worst of the six tracks. The material is rough, theoretical, and largely inapplicable to daily life (save for the moral inquiries, though even they have their own practical flaws). That said, the ideas are pure, and especially in final season, it's very rewarding to see everything come together and fully comprehend the ways in which one author influences another. So, I'm not sure I'd recommend spring phil on its own, but within the confines of DS, it should absolutely be taken.
Probably not
I would probably recommend a different prof given how many options you have in DS. Find someone with more zest for the DS setting
Yes! Even if they are not pursuing philosophy further, this course is a great foundation on intellectual history
Yes, as it enabled me to talk intelligently on important philosophers.
